glossary.Description: Citation technique developed by the American Psychological Association (APA) for subjects in the social sciences.

A citation is the direct reference to a source used. This can be done in the text called 'in-text citation' where information such as the author's last name, year of publication and page numbers in some instances is provided. A reference list is made up of a number of citations.
Citation technique developed by the Modern Language Association (MLA) for subjects in the humanities.
Involves recording the main points of information that is relevant to you after scanning.
Involves re-writing information extracted from other sources in your own words.
Plagiarism is an act of literary theft, where one passes off the ideas or words of other as one's own, without crediting the source.

A collection of resources used in the report. This includes printed and electronic resources such as books, journals, CD-ROMs, the Internet, online databases. A Reference List is also known as a bibliography.
Involves reading through a relevant document very quickly to look for specific information or facts.
A quick read of the document to determine the gist or essence of the contents.
